section_title: Revision Total Hip Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 25, L894)
names: Revision Total Hip Arthroplasty (Evidence: pg no: 25, L894)
description: Revision total hip arthroplasty is considered medically necessary when at least ONE of the following conditions is present. (Evidence: pg no: 25, L895-L896)
scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

documentation: Substantial osteolysis of the weight bearing surfaces with or without periarticular osteolysis (Evidence: pg no: 25, L898)
Progressive soft tissue or bone reaction including symptomatic synovitis (Evidence: pg no: 25, L899)
Component instability, failure, or recall (Evidence: pg no: 25, L900)
Displaced periprosthetic fracture or irreducible dislocation (Evidence: pg no: 25, L901)
Hip reconstruction after previous removal of prosthesis due to infection or catastrophic failure (Evidence: pg no: 25, L902)
Metal on metal implant: An elevated synovial cobalt level, An increased cobalt/chromium level (Evidence: pg no: 25, L903-L906)
Recurrent disabling pain or significant functional disability that persists despite at least 3 months of conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 26, L907-L908)

codes.description: Revision of total hip arthroplasty; both components, with or without autograft or allograft (Evidence: pg no: 27, L976)
Revision of total hip arthroplasty; acetabular component only, with or without autograft or allograft (Evidence: pg no: 27, L977)
Revision of total hip arthroplasty; femoral component only, with or without allograft (Evidence: pg no: 27, L978)
